title: In the Drops: Panaracer Agilest tyres, Cyclus Tools barbecue, Enervit nutrition and becoming your own bike mechanic

In the Drops: Panaracer Agilest tyres, Cyclus Tools barbecue, Enervit nutrition and becoming your own bike mechanic

This week has felt very much like the calm before storm the men’s 2023 Tour de France will no doubt unleash when it starts tomorrow. Nonetheless, we at Cyclist have been building up to it nicely.

We kicked off with week with Brit-focussed pro coverage, speaking to Bahrain Victorious’s Fred Wright and running a gallery on the British National Road Championships. Even this week’s Pro Log was UK-centric.

From Tuesday onwards we started gearing up for the Tour. We looked at the race favourites and some of climbs that will no doubt help shape the fortunes of those favourites and we broke down how to watch this year’s race. Be sure to check out the article on our predictions about this year’s race when it is published a little later today too.

While the week has been pro-dominated, tech coverage hasn’t been been forgotten. We refreshed both our general road bike groupsets buyer’s guide as well as our SRAM road and gravel groupsets buyer’s guide (thanks to the recent launch of the brand’s Apex AXS groupset), covered a natty new app from CeramicSpeed that helps the rider care for their bike and looked at an AI-generated paint scheme adorning FDJ’s Lapierre Xelius 10.0 Tour bikes this year. Plus we reviewed the Castelli Rosso Corsa 2 women’s mitts as well. As is only right and proper, we round out the week tech-wise with another edition of In the Drops, so without further ado, let’s get in to it.

Panaracer Agilest TLR tyres

The latest addition to Panaracer’s line of road tyres is the tubeless Agilest TLR, which has been designed for all-season riding. The 120tpi carcass is woven from Panaracer’s AX-Alpha Cord, a nylon thread that claims to deliver a ‘supple and grippy’ ride, while the manufacturer says the ZSG Agile tread compound has ‘12% lower rolling resistance than previous models’.

Similar to brands such as Schwalbe with its MicroSkin, the Agilest TLR has a butyl membrane bonded around the inside of the tyre to aid air retention, while the tyre bead is compatible with hookless and hooked rims. Sizes range from 25mm to 32mm, and amber (read: tan-wall) versions will shortly be available too.

These 28mm Agilest TLR tyres weigh 240g a piece, which compares well to their main competitors such as Vittoria’s Corsa N.EXT tyres and Continental’s GP5000 TR, and they do feel supple in hand as well. While a comprehensive judgement would require a full review, on the face of it these are encouraging signs for Panaracer’s latest road tyre.

Cyclus Tools Charcoal Mini Barbecue and Tongs

Cyclus Tools is best known for its European-made workshop-quality tools, but right at the back of its extensive catalogue the brand also offers some more esoteric products.

The highlight of which has to be this mini charcoal barbecue. It might be novel but it’s far from a gimmick: the body is constructed from sturdy sheets of stainless steel and it has been shaped in such a way as to evenly spread heat across the grill area – which is around the size of a bit of A4 paper – from a small central shelf.

Consequently, it only requires a small amount of charcoal to kick out an impressive level of heat for an impressive amount of time. Those who try to use it to cater for bigger garden parties would be left wanting, but for a quick evening grill for up to about four people, this little thing is perfect.

Cyclus even thought to include tongs shaped like 22mm cone spanners. In terms of cycling-themed everyday products, I’m putting this right up there with Park Tool’s PZT-2 bike pizza cutter, and maybe even Campagnolo’s iconic Big Corkscrew.

Enervit C2:1 Pro nutrition products

I did a degree in Sports Nutrition and Physiology a long time ago and considering the fees I paid I remember depressingly little (although this is more representative of my memory than the quality of the course I took). One bit of knowledge that I have retained however is the concept of Multiple Transportable Carbohydrates.

Put crudely, MTC explains that different types of sugar (sucrose, fructose, glucose, etc) rely on different transporters for intestinal absorption, meaning that even if a threshold amount of one type of sugar has been ingested (it is thought that pure glucose can been used at a rate of 60g/hour), the body can continue to absorb and use other types (even on top of glucose digestion, it is believed that fructose can be used at 30g/hour).

The implication of this in a cycling sense is that the rider has more energy available to use if their nutrition contains more than one type of sugar. Enter Enervit’s C2:1 Pro range.

As the name suggests, the C2:1 Pro range blends glucose and fructose together to allow the rider to absorb sugar at resultant rate of 90g/hour. Enervit offers the range in a variety of forms, so while the energy-giving properties of the product remain the same, the rider can vary the source to avoid consumption fatigue (getting bored of eating/drinking the same thing) on really long rides. Enervit sponsors Tadej Pogačar’s UAE Team Emirates, so no doubt those guys will appreciate the variety at this year’s Tour de France.

Alongside the traditional gel, there is a thicker jelly, a drink powder mix, a more substantial oat-based bar and even some energy chew blocks, which I like to think of as Haribo on steroids.

What we’re into this week: Tinkering

For both professional and personal reasons (as my job is also my hobby), there is always a baseline level of ongoing bike maintenance in my life. Recently though, through a combination of circumstance and necessity, I’ve been spending more of my time (both inside and outside of my contracted hours) working on bikes, as opposed to just simply riding and writing about them.

The more mundane, everyday tasks sometimes make it easy for me to forget to appreciate the satisfaction I find in making sure the bike I’m riding is ship-shape. So, the out-of-the-ordinary tasks I’ve been doing recently have reminded me that riding bikes is just one of the myriad levels on which cycling-focussed lifestyle can be enjoyed.

I understand that people may not have the time or desire to apply existing knowledge or learn something new in order to personally care for their bikes, but should the inclination be there I’d recommend you absolutely scratch that itch.

Some tasks require an advanced level of mechanical expertise that your local bike shop is definitely still best placed to complete. However, in large part the bicycle is a very simple machine that is easy enough to maintain with basic tools, a little bit of common sense and maybe an instructional YouTube video or two (we’ve even made a few of those ourselves), so don’t be shy about wrapping those bars, adding preload to that headset or realigning that brake calliper. Ticking jobs off a tinkering to-do list will improve your experience on the road and a well-maintained bike will last longer too, so you’ll no doubt save some money as well. Win-win.
